div.head:
Embleme 14. Of the Secrets of Nature.
This is the Dragon which devours his tayle.

lg.l: Hunger taught Polypus his flesh to eat,
And man with man his appetite to treat:
The hungry Dragon feeding on his tayle,
His fainting soule releivesrelieves, which els would faylefail;
Hold him to hard meat, till himselfe hee doe
Eat and devouredevour, kill and revive anew.

div.head: Discourse 14.
div.ab:
It is a saying of the Ancients, that a Serpent, which hath devourddevoured a Serpent, be
comes a Dragon: for it is cruellcruel to its kind, as a theifethief and Murderer to his: It is-
evident that such are in Africa, of soe great bignessebigness and plenty, that they-
destroyed a great part of Alexanders army: Amongst the Asachæi a people-
of ÆthiopiaEthiopia are very great produced, which being wrapdwrapped together after-
the manner of hurdles doe with their heads lifted up make way to better-
pasture. They report that the Kings of India maintaindmaintained two Dragons, one
of eighty, and the other of ninety cubits in bignessebigness: by the observation of
later writers and now adayesnowadays it is knowne, that near Angola are found such
as are æquall to the great masts of ships: Soe they report that in some cer
taine mountains of India and Africa there is great store of gold, but kept by
dragons, lest any one come thither and take it away: For dragons doe resort-
to fountains or rivers, which fall from the mountains, and soe are sayd to watch
the gold by accident: for this reason doe the Philosophers ascribe soe many-
dragons or serpents to their treasures, as to the golden Fleece, the garden of the-
Hesperides, and to other persons or Chymicall subjects, to Cadmus, Saturne, Æscu
lapiusEsculapius, Mercury, whose wand is begirt with two Serpents, male and female: but
doe they meane nothing els by Dragons, but Chymicall subjects? Hereupon-
say they, the Dragons yeild mountains, and the earth fountains to Rebis,-
and denoting the extreme hunger of the dragon in devouring his tayle: which
though others may interpret of the year returning into itselfe, and resembling
a circle, yet it was accomodatedaccommodated by the Philosophers to their things, who-
by this dragon would have a Serpent understood, which devouresdevours another of
its owne kind, and this is properly called Sulphur, as they all attest in innume
rable places: Lully in his little booke chapt. 31. This is, sayth hee, Sulphur,
my Sonne! and this the Serpent and dragon devouring his tayle, the roar
ing lyon, and sharp sword, cutting, mortifying, and tearing all things. And
the Rosary: The Dragon dyes not, unlesse hee be killd with his brother-
and Sister. And a little after: The Dragon is Argent vive extracted from
bodyes, having in it a body, Soule, and spirit: This is in the same place
called by another name ffæctidfetid water, which is produced after the separation
of the Elements: Now the Dragon is sayd to devour his tayle, in consuming
the voluble, venomous, and moist part, that after without a tayle hee-
may seem more corpulent and of lesse Speed, for the motion and volu
bility of him consisted cheifely in his tayle: Other animalls depend upon
feet, but dragons, Serpents, and wormesworms of that kind doe use constriction and
explication of body instead of feet, and as it were water pourepour out doe di
vide into certaine courses, inclining themselves sometimes this way some
times that, as you may see in allmost all rivers, how they turne their-
courses like Serpents, and runne obliquely in circuits: they did not there
fore without reason call Argent vive a Serpent, and and add serpents to Mer
cury, it allso drawing as it were a tayle, and running sometimes this-
sometimes that way with a voluble poise: For as a Serpent creeps soe
allso Mercury, who hath therefore wings upon his feet and head.-
Discourse 14.
In AffricaAfrica they say are flying Serpents, which would waste and depopu
late all things, if they were not destroyd by the bird calld Ibis: For which
cause Ibis is erected amongst the sacred Ægyptian images, both for the mani
fest utility, which it performesperforms to the whole country, and for an occult-
reason, which very few men have understood. This dragon biting of his-
tayle, and casting his old skinne is sayd to acquire a new one together with
youth, as nature hath granted longer life not onely to Crows, Ravens, Eagles,
and Harts, but allso to the Serpentine kind: The Ant growing old acquirethacquires-
wings, soe allso many wormes: Man growing old is put into the earth, but
being revived from the earth will be consecrated to æternall life. Of every-
Serpent burned is made a powder, which is taken safely against all poy
sons with great effect: Such an Alexipharmacum ought allso to be made-
of this dragon (who hath allready devoured his tayle, which is usually cutt
of in Vipers) a most effectuall remedy against the adversityesadversities of for
tune and body. . . . . . . . . . . .
